verb.description: Grasp or seize (something) tightly or eagerly.
examples: Mrs. Longhill clutched at the idea

noun.description: A tight grasp or an act of grasping something.
examples: she made a clutch at his body

noun.description: A mechanism for connecting and disconnecting a vehicle engine from its transmission system.
A slim, flat handbag without handles or a strap.

adjective.description: (in sport) denoting or occurring in a critical situation in which the outcome of a game or competition is at stake.
examples: they both are hard-nosed players who seem to thrive in clutch situations

phrases: apparently everyone at the film festival is clutching their pearls in horror over the explicit sex scenes in his new film
why are some athletes able to perform in the clutch while others choke?
Hunte also spoke highly of his two veteran players, Vernon Lewis and Kane Easter, who both came through in the clutch.
It's not that robots don't bleed, but more that they don't play hurt, or brawl, or choke in the clutch.
But the arrogance that enables him to be such a reliable shooter in the clutch prevents him from countenancing the fact that he's a defensive liability.
origin: Early 18th century: probably a southern variant of northern English dialect cletch, related to Middle English cleck to hatch, from Old Norse klekja.
